entry.title: How to monitor consumption for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and its components?
entry.content:
Symptom: You don't know how to check SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) usage.

Requirements: You need to have an S-user and the role of Super Administrator assigned in SAP for Me. 

  • If you don't have an S-User, please check this page.
  • If you are unsure which role you have, please check this note. 

Resolution:

1) Open SAP for Me and log in.

2) Navigate to the "Dashboards" section and click "Finance & Legal".

3) Select "Consumption".

4) Filter for "Business Data Cloud".

5) Click on the measured number to open a card; it explains the consumption by each metric. 

Image 01

 

Image 2

Important reminder: SAP Databricks and SAP Datasphere usage is based on actual consumption instead of what is in the quota assignment. For SAP Analytics Cloud, on the other hand, it is considered the number of users assigned for each SAC license according to the quota assignment. For more information on the components usage (SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere), please refer to this documentation. If you want to know more about how the metric itself works, check this pdf.

entry.title: Re: Has anyone extended CALM?
entry.content:
Hi @XavierPicquart ,

Thank you for your reply. Let me address your points.

1. For example, the customer does not want to receive a notification for every error, but only after the third error. Currently, CALM can only generate a notification for the first error or for every error. I could take this further with my own logic, e.g. that the notifications must follow a certain pattern. All the data is available in CALM, I just need to integrate it. I have read that CALM was built on the basis of CAP. CAP projects can be individually extended. Does CALM offer this option?

2. By apps, I meant adding your own apps to the CALM Launchpad. Creating your own tile that points to your own development. Unfortunately, I couldn't find anything on this. For example, an extension is being developed in the BTP for monitoring, and this should be easily accessible in CALM for the basis.

3. Is there a type of content federation like in s4? Roles, apps, etc.

4. Is it possible to access the data via a Hana Cloud instance? Remote source or replication?

5. Which APIs are you referring to? I'm talking about adding buttons to standard apps, for example, essentially an adaptation project. Ideally, the underlying service can also be extended.

6. Are there any further details available? Including the available features?

Best regards

Andre

entry.title: Crystal Reports running extremely slow in SAGE after PC Upgrade
entry.content:
Hello, we have recently encountered and issue with Crystal Reports in Sage Timberline/300 CRE running extremely slowly on some new PCs that were deployed.

Not all accounting PCs were replaced, the user still using an 'older' PC is able to run a large report in 2-3 minutes. The same large report takes 10min+ on one of the 'new' machines.

Two newer machines were deployed and exhibit the exact same symptoms.

We whitelisted Sage and Crystal reports in Antivirus even though all 3 systems use the same antivirus.

We reinstalled the entirety of Sage and Crystal reports

We exported registry keys from the working machine to make sure 32 and 64bit ODBC drivers matched 100%

We tried to run the report pointing to different printer drivers

SFC and DISM scans have been run on the machines and pass clean

Nothing else was replaced networking wise, switches, etc. These users have the same connection to the LAN they had before when the reports ran fine.

NEW
HP Elite Mini 800 G9 Desktop PC
12th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-12700T (20 virtual) (X64)
16GB RAM
Win 11 Pro


OLD
HP ProDesk 600 G3 DM
Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700T CPU @ 2.80GHz (8 virtual) (X64)
16GB RAM
Win 10 Pro

 

Any help or advise anyone can provide is greatly appreciated, thanks in advance!!

entry.title: cycle count completion indicator
entry.content: We moved to S4 Hana with EWM just this May. Nailing down cycle counts has been challenging. We operate in two warehouses under the same roof, raw materials and finished goods. All parts selected for count are counted in all warehouses and all locations. The issue we are having is accurate reflection of whether a part has been counted or not. Our ABC parts are broken out as such, A parts counted every qtr or 4 times a year, B parts every six months or 2X per year and C parts 1 per year. We may count a part today and trace completion results back through - Physical Inventory Progress>Cycle Counting. In the upper table we select "All Products".  The lower table displays all products. Within that table there are multiple columns. We have been instructed to focus on the column "Compl.Sts" to determine if count requirements have been met for the period for that line-item part. Those items that do not have a "X" are those that have not been counted per the requirements within the period. Our problem is that we have seen time and again on many parts that on the day we count, the "X" is present. Then when viewing the same tile following the same path, the "X" indicating completed is no longer populated. As a result, we end up counting the same part numbers multiple times across days and weeks. Some part numbers we count are flagged with the "X" that remains without issue. So, we are trying to understand why the counted flag for the parts affected doesn't remain causing additional, unnecessary counts and also creates issue when trying to explain to outside auditors. Are we looking in the wrong area? Do we have flags not set or set incorrectly? What steps do we need to take so we get accurate data?

entry.title: PROMOTION
entry.content:
Hello community,
I am working as an HR/system lead using SAP HCM (on-premise), and I need to implement a promotion process for employees (change in job role/pay grade/cost center, etc.). I would appreciate your guidance with the end-to-end steps. Specifically:

  1. Which personnel action (in transaction PA40) should be used for promotion, and how do you configure it?

  2. Which infotypes typically must be updated (e.g., IT0001, IT0008, etc.) in the promotion scenario?

  3. How to configure the workflow (if any) so that the promotion request goes for approval before the data is committed?

  4. How to ensure that the promotion is correctly reflected in the system (history of infotypes, no gaps/overlaps)?

  5. What are best practices or pitfalls to watch out for when doing promotions in SAP HCM?

  6. If there is a version of this for integration with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, how does it differ?

I have already done some configuration, but I‚Äôm not confident that I‚Äôm covering everything‚Äîespecially from the technical side (action/reason code settings, infotype validity, workflows). If anyone has a test script, configuration guide, or can share the necessary transactions and settings step-by-step, I‚Äôd be very grateful.

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Best practices and process design for using Procurement Type ‚ÄúX‚Äù (Make-or-Buy) in SAP ERP
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

I‚Äôm currently working on a project dealing with the configuration and process implications of using Procurement Type ‚ÄúX‚Äù (both in-house and external procurement) for semi-finished and assembly materials in an SAP environment.

Our goal is to understand whether procurement type ‚ÄúX‚Äù can be implemented effectively and what process controls and reporting designs are needed to maintain costing accuracy, transparency, and audit compliance,  or whether using two separate material numbers (one for in-house, one for external) is the more sustainable approach.

In our analysis, we have identified advantages (e.g. reduced master data maintenance, simplified BOMs, flexible quota arrangements) and disadvantages (e.g. mixed costing, valuation inconsistencies, transparency and audit concerns, high coordination effort between SCM and Controlling).

I‚Äôd like to ask the community for insights or best practices on the following:

  1. Process design:
    What does a clean, transparent process for reconciling in-house and external procurement under procurement type ‚ÄúX‚Äù look like, especially regarding communication and data maintenance between SCM and Controlling?

  2. Costing and valuation:
    How do you handle mixed costing or valuation when the in-house/external ratio changes dynamically during the year? Are there SAP-standard functionalities or best-practice workarounds to ensure consistent costing and stock valuation?

  3. Reporting and traceability:
    What reporting setups or SAP tools (standard or custom) are commonly used to analyze internal vs. external shares under procurement type ‚ÄúX‚Äù?
    How do you maintain audit-proof transparency in such cases?

  4. Governance and system configuration:
    Are there recommended decision criteria or governance frameworks (e.g. when to use procurement type X vs. separate materials) used in practice to balance flexibility vs. compliance?

I‚Äôm particularly interested in learning from companies that successfully implemented procurement type X for Make-or-Buy scenarios without losing control over costing, valuation, and transparency.

Thank you in advance for your insights and experiences!
Best regards!

entry.title: Where to maintain the Tax Identification Number (VAT / Tax ID) in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We are implementing SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 for both corporate accounts and individual customers, and we cannot find any field to maintain the Tax Identification Number (Tax ID / VAT ID).

In previous SAP systems such as SAP CRM, SAP ECC, or SAP S/4HANA, the tax number is a mandatory and country-dependent field, including format validations, duplicate checks, and legal controls.

In Sales Cloud V2, we only find the section Identification Types under the Account entity, but this seems to be designed for external IDs and doesn‚Äôt provide:

  • Country-specific validation rules,

  • Duplicate management,

  • Search or match functionality,

  • Integration relevance for invoicing or fiscal documents.

This information is critical in any commercial scenario, as the Tax ID uniquely identifies the customer and is required for downstream processes in ERP billing and legal compliance.

My questions:

  1. Where should the Tax Identification Number be maintained in the standard Sales Cloud V2 data model?

  2. Is SAP planning to introduce a dedicated field or validation logic for this purpose?

  3. Are there any recommended best practices or workarounds (for example, using the Account Identification entity with a specific ID Type)?

Thanks in advance for your insights.

Best regards,
Jorge Ocampos
SAP CX Consultant

entry.title: Re: Data synchronize not happening in the EABLG and EABL...
entry.content:
• Was there any instance of an unwanted outage, technical issue in the time-window of those records on your SAP-system?
  • Were there any Dumps / UpdateErrors etc.?
  • Does your situation correspond to the behaviour mentioned in Notes such as 3349117 - EL37 leaves inconsistent meter reading documents (EABL without EABLG) - SAP for Me / 3349538 - Error prevention mechanism for inconsistent meter reading documents (EABL without EABLG) - SAP for Me / 1091077 - Enhanced error prev mech SAPSQL_ARRAY_INSERT_DUPREC w/ EABL - SAP for Me / 2145663 - Error prevention mechanism for inconsistent meter reading documents (EABL without EABLG) - SAP for Me / 2439650 - After change / reversal: EABL without EABLG - SAP for Me ...
  • And quite important : Are there any BAdIs / UExits or other forms of Custom coding involved that could possibly have side-effects or bugs?

If answers to (all of) the above is "NO", you should raise a SAP-Support Ticket ...
Inconsistencies shouldn't occur, and if they do, it should be traceable in "ST22" "SM21" "SM13" or other logs of some kind. Check for SAP-Notes to upgrade your system.

You should try to trace back to the steps where the specific EABL-EABLG records were created or changed, and try to match that to what logs provide as evidence ...

Hope this helps

Nic T.

entry.title: SAP Developer News October 30th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

PODCAST: https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/10/30/sap-developer-news-october-30th-2025/ 

 

Devtoberfest Digest 

  • Devtoberfest Digest: https://url.sap/devtoberfest-digest 

 

Documentation collaboration and contributions 

  • Building Enterprise Grade CAP applications using BTP Developer's guide https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tUKMUIL9C6k  
  • Get to know more about CAP‚Äôs documentation offering https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gvjbxitDf18 
  • SAP BTP Developers Guide https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/btp-developers-guide/btp-developers-guide 
  • Open Documentation Initiative (podcast episode) https://podcast.opensap.info/open-source-way/2021/11/24/the-open-documentation-initiative-the-gold-standard-of-collaborative-documentation/  
  • Runtime Comparison Guide https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/comparison-btp-runtimes/runtime-comparison 

 

SAP TechEd 

  • Event Page: https://www.sap.com/events/teched.html 

 

SAP Community Voice 

  • October SAP Community Voice Post: https://community.sap.com/t5/what-s-new/sap-community-voice-get-ready-for-sap-teched-certifications-and-upcoming/ba-p/14255481 
  • Video Playlist: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLpQebylHrdh5ZmJeJXl_pC9n7LcsfFjrZ&si=gr0wPQhCkXiWHhLC 

 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 Devtoberfest Digest 

2:13 Documentation collaboration and contributions 

4:03 SAP TechEd  

4:36 SAP Community Voice 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for October 30th, 2025.

[Antonio & Javier] Hola, SAP Developers. We just wrapped up Devtoberfest last week, but I know that many of you are still trying to catch up with all the great content that's part of Devtoberfest. Well, my friend Javier here developed a very nice tool called Devtoberfest Digest that can help you with this. Javier, can you share with us a bit about what Devtoberfest Digest is and what was your motivation to develop it? Hello, this is Javier Martin from the BTP solution advisory team in Spain. And well, the Devtoberfest Digest is an AI-powered solution that kind of watches all the sessions that you deliver on the event and magically extracts the relevant information from the different videos so you can get the key points and relevant data for your interests. Perfect. And what was your motivation to develop it? Well, my motivation, yeah, let's say that I heard that there was some new MCP servers that was already released, like the CAP and the Fiori MCP servers, so I wanted to test them out. And, well, I was kind of struggling with time, right, to follow all the great sessions, so just the idea came really quickly. Fantastic. And what are some of the technologies that power Devtoberfest Digest? So for the backend, I use CAP, a cloud application programming model. There is Fiori as well for the frontend, HANA Cloud for persistence. And I'm also using the orchestration service from the generative failure hub for LLM access. Nice. And where is it that everyone can access this tool? Yeah, so the tool is already developed on the BTP. We already created a short URL for you guys to consume it and well, I hope you find it useful. I'm sure I will find it useful because there are many sessions that I still need to catch up. Definitely. So thank you very much for sharing this with the community and I hope you all enjoy it. Thank you. Ciao.

[DJ] Here is a shout out to all you lovely content collaborators. During Devtoberfest, we had a couple of great sessions on documentation and documentation contributions. Ren√© and Mahadi gave us a great overview of the CAP documentation and explained the different ways you can get involved by sharing feedback or contributing content. Gopal talked about enterprise-grade capabilities for CAP apps with information based upon the SAP BTP Developers Guide, which is also open for collaboration as well. Don't forget that the Open Documentation Initiative is still very much alive and well, with plenty of documentation sets. In fact, there's been a recent edition of the Runtime Comparison Guide, and there are also still contribution badges to be earned, as well as just cool points from having your GitHub avatar listed in the repo. Alternatively, you can also just leave a question or comment directly on the relevant page in the SAP Help Portal if you wish‚Äîthe choice is yours. By the way, talking of the SAP BTP Developers Guide, this has had some updates and improvements recently. There's a new strengths and benefits section for all major runtimes, there's a new security guide with info for all the different relevant aspects or development phases of CAP development. And there's also a new section on developing software-as-a-service offerings, especially interesting, I suppose, for SAP partners and other software vendors. Anyway, have a look at the documentation and get involved.

[Tom] You might have noticed that the SAP Developer News was a little lighter this week. Well, that's probably because next week is SAP TechEd. And of course, who would have news about a new release or a new feature coming out just the week before TechEd? Of course, we're going to have tons of news from SAP TechEd virtual and Berlin and TechEd on tour. So be on the lookout for special episodes of the SAP Developer News next week, live from Berlin. We will bring you all the updates and announcements from the event. But speaking of SAP TechEd, we also have the Community Voice. And this is a new offering, kind of a monthly newsletter format to keep you abreast of all things that are going on in the SAP community. This month, they have a lot of information to help you get ready for TechEd and get the most out of it. They also have a wrap-up of Devtoberfest, information about new certifications, blog highlights, all kinds of good content. So be sure to check that out. Make a great thing to read as you're getting ready to travel to SAP TechEd or SAP TechEd on tour. And if you are going to be there in Berlin next week or Sydney or India later in the month, we look forward to seeing you there. So until then, have a great trip and a great TechEd.

entry.title: Check the Purchasing document status managed by Flexible Workflow as a creator

entry.title: What‚Äôs new with SAP Business AI, Joule, and Joule Agents in the SAP SuccessFactors 2H 2025 release
entry.content:
SAP SuccessFactors‚Äô second half 2025 release represents a major leap forward for AI capabilities across our HCM solutions, beginning with the introduction of our first of many planned AI agents. These agents, led by SAP‚Äôs copilot, Joule, mark a pivotal shift in how HR leaders will use artificial intelligence to create more responsive, efficient, and human-centered workplaces. Let‚Äôs look at our new AI agent and some other key AI-related highlights in the 2H 2025 release.

Empowering Managers with the Performance and Goals Agent

The newly available Performance and Goals Agent helps managers lead more meaningful performance conversations. By automatically gathering relevant data, from goals and achievements to feedback, Joule delivers personalized discussion points and suggests follow-up actions like scheduling one-on-one meetings or updating goals. This elevates coaching from administrative to strategic, enabling truly continuous performance management. If you want to learn more about the AI agents for HCM announced recently at SAP Connect, please visit this page.

 Joule Integration with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Through its integration with Microsoft 365 Copilot, Joule now connects data and workflows from Teams, Outlook, OneDrive, and SharePoint directly within SAP SuccessFactors. This unified experience reduces the need to switch between systems, letting users complete tasks, retrieve insights, and make decisions directly in the flow of work.

Smarter Pay Transparency with Explain Pay

Employee Central Payroll users in Germany, Mexico, and Brazil can now access the Explain Pay feature in Joule. The capability provides natural-language explanations for pay-related questions, cutting resolution time by up to 50%. This delivers the transparency and trust employees increasingly expect while decreasing HR support load.

Expanding Generative AI Access and Joule Actions

SAP has expanded generative AI availability to private-sector customers in Saudi Arabia, offering AI-assisted writing and goal-setting across HR workflows. The update also broadens Joule Actions, allowing users to upload files, view employer information, access extended time-off data, and create half-day leave requests, all via conversational prompts.

Learn More

In short, the 2H 2025 release of SAP SuccessFactors strengthens the platform‚Äôs role as an intelligent, interconnected HR ecosystem that drives productivity, trust, and engagement, all powered by Joule and SAP Business AI. You can discover more 2H 2025 innovations across the suite by checking out the release highlights brochure, overview video featuring Bianka Woelke, and much more on the Product Release & Road Map Information page.

Together, these innovations demonstrate SAP‚Äôs vision for an HR future where AI doesn‚Äôt just support processes, it redefines them. By embedding agentic intelligence throughout SuccessFactors, SAP gives HR leaders the tools to transform data into action, decisions into impact, and every moment at work into a more connected, individualized experience.

entry.title: Issue in SAP BPA Standard Flow ‚ÄúAutomatic Creation of Sales Order from Unstructured Data (5LT)‚Äù
entry.content:
Hello experts,

We are implementing the SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) standard content ‚ÄúAutomatic Creation of Sales Order from Unstructured Data (5LT)‚Äù to automatically create sales orders in SAP from customer documents received via email.

However, we are facing an issue of email Signature Images Also Getting Posted in Sales Order Request

This leads to unnecessary attachments being processed and posted in SAP.

What we have checked so far

  • The incoming email to BPA includes one main PDF (order document) and multiple inline PNG files from the sender‚Äôs signature.

  • The BPA flow processes all attachments together without filtering based on file type or content.

Our questions

  1. Is there a standard way in this BPA flow to filter attachments so that only relevant documents (e.g., PDFs) are considered for processing?

  2. If not, what is the recommended approach or extension point to add such filtering logic?

Any pointers or configuration guidance would be appreciated.

Thanks & Regards
Aman Mittal

I created a freestyle application configured with an OData V2 service. After generating the project, I added an annotations.xml file to define the columns for my entity type. Then, I added a SmartTable controller bound to my entity.

However, the columns are not being displayed in the SmartTable.
Could you please help me understand what might be missing or incorrectly configured?

Thank you.

Main.view.xml

<mvc:View
    controllerName="dummy3.controller.Main"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:smartTable="sap.ui.comp.smarttable"
>
    <Page
        id="page"
        title="{i18n>title}"
    >
        <smartTable:SmartTable
            id="idSalesOrderSmartTable"
            entitySet="ZC_SALESORDER_HEADER"
            header="Sales Order"
            enableAutoBinding="true"
        />
    </Page>
</mvc:View>

Main.controller.ts

import SmartTable from "sap/ui/comp/smarttable/SmartTable";
import Controller from "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller";
import ODataModel from "sap/ui/model/odata/v2/ODataModel";

/**
 * @namespace dummy3.controller
 */
export default class Main extends Controller {

    /*eslint-disable @typescript-eslint/no-empty-function*/
    public onInit(): void {

        const serviceUri = this.getOwnerComponent()!.getManifestEntry("/sap.app/dataSources").mainService.uri;
        console.log("serviceUri: " + serviceUri);
        const model = new ODataModel(serviceUri);

        this.getView()!.setModel(model);
    }
}

entry.title: Business Communication System
entry.content:
Hi Team,


How to create a Communication System for new subaccount?

 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Business Communication System
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

 

To create a communication system perform the following steps:

  1. On the initial screen of the Communication Systems app, click New.
  2. In the New Communication System dialog define an ID and a name of the new system.
  3. Make the required settings under:

    • General Data
      Enter system ID and system name.
      Contact Information
      Enter name, email or phone number of a contact person.

    • Technical Data
      Host Name: Enter the host name of the remote system for outgoing API service calls. Please note that the usage of localhost is not allowed as host name.

      UI Host Name: Enter the host name of the remote system for UI-related integration options (This entry is optional. If nothing is defined here, the API host name is used.)

      Logical System: Here you can define an alternative ID for the logical system that is required for IDoc communication.

      Business System: Here you can define an alternative ID for the business system that identifies the communication system in your system landscape.

      Port: Enter the HTTP port. The default setting is 443.

      Cipher Suites: Here you can define a set of encryption mechanisms you want to use as a basis for your communication. You can choose between different versions of TLS (Transport Layer Security). A default value is defined by the system and you can change this if required.

      Is Hub System: Depending on the underlying communication scenario, you can trigger B2B messages from Output Management for Electronic Data Interchange (EDI).

      If you are using a central hub such as SAP Ariba to which all your B2B messages are sent, select the Is Hub System checkbox. Alternatively, assign the required business partner to the communication system. Please note that only business partners of the type Organization are supported.

      Inbound Only: If you want your communication system to be used for a communication arrangement based on a communication scenario that only contains inbound services, we recommend that you select the Inbound Only checkbox. If this checkbox is selected, the input fields that are only required for outbound communication disappear.

      Cloud Connector switch: Indicates that the Cloud Connector is used for communication with this system.

      SSC Location ID: Enter the Cloud Connector ID

      If your scenario is uses RFC modules, and the Cloud Connector is not activated, the system uses WebSocket RFC. Therefore the remote system needs to support WebSocket RFC and you need to specify the client in the RFC Settings section.

      RFC Settings: Define additional settings needed for RFC communication.

      OAuth 2.0 Settings: Define additional settings if oAuth 2.0 is used.

      Note: The propagation of technical users from the cloud application towards on-premise systems can be enabled in the Communication Systems app. To propagate the technical user, you have to select the Cloud Conn. Technical User Propagation checkbox in the OAuth 2.0 Settings area (the checkbox is only active if the Cloud Connector switch is on). This is similar to principal propagation, but in this case, a technical user is propagated instead of a business user. When creating inbound users for oAuth 2.0, you can select the Refresh Allowed checkbox and define a Refresh Token Expiry Time in days, months or years. The default setting is two days.

      Remote SQL Access switch: Define additional settings needed to access remote databases via SQL:

      Select the required Adapter Name. This specifies the corresponding HANA Smart Data Access adapter and the type of access method to be used by the SAP HANA database to access the data. Use the field input help for the list of adapter names you can specify.

      Enter the required Adapter Configuration. This specifies the connection parameters for a given adapter.

      OAuth 2.0 Identity Provider switch: Before you can authenticate and get an access token to access resources using an OAuth 2.0 client, you have to configure a trusted relationship to the required SAML Identity Provider (token issuer).

      Upload the signing certificate of the trusted provider and define the provider name.

      Define the User ID Mapping Mode if you don't use e-mail addresses, but either logon name or global user ID.

      The User ID Mapping Mode is required when the SAML Identity Provider is creating SAML assertions with the NameIdentifierFormat unspecified.

      This setting is ignored when then SAML assertion is using the NameIdentifierFormat eMailAddress.

      Please note that the required authorization for calling the service is granted to the business user and not to the technical user. When you set up a communication arrangement using oAuth, you can click OAuth 2.0 Details, select the scope and click Granted by Business Catalogs to find the necessary details. This way you can retrieve the business catalogs that are required for calling the service.

      SAML Bearer Assertion Provider switch: Before you can authenticate using SAML2 Bearer assertions transmitted via the authorization header, you have to configure a trusted relationship to the required SAML Identity Provider (token issuer).

      Upload the signing certificate of the trusted provider and define the provider name.

      Define the required User ID Mapping Mode if it is unspecified and you don't use e-mail addresses, but either logon name or user UUID.

      The User ID Mapping Mode is required when the SAML Identity Provider is creating SAML assertions with the NameIdentifierFormat unspecified .

      This setting is ignored when then SAML assertion is using the NameIdentifierFormat eMailAddress.

      OpenID Connect switch: Before you can authenticate using OpenID Connect, you have to configure a trusted OpenID Connect Provider.

      Define the required User ID Mapping Mode, the OIDC Token Issuer and Client ID. Click Import Metadata. This is necessary to ensure that the configuration is validated and complete.

      If the automatic configuration fails, you can configure the OpenID Connect settings manually. For more information, see Manual Configuration - OpenID Connect (OIDC) Provider in the Related Information section.

       
  4. Add technical users for inbound and/or outbound communication. You can either select a user from the list or create a new user. If you decide to create a new user for inbound communication, you can click New User and you will be redirected to the Maintain Communication Users app. For more information about authentication methods for outbound users, see the Related Information section.

    Inbound users are communication users provided by your system and are used by the communication system to call the inbound services. Outbound users are communication users provided by the external communication system to call the outbound services.

  5. Save your changes.

    You can now establish a communication arrangement with the created system. Use the Communication Arrangements app for this purpose.

 

If you have a specific scenario, please discuss with your SAP Representative. 

 

Kind regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: Cloud ALM Tenant extension greater than 24GB
entry.content:
Hello Team,

Our CloudALM usage already hit 24GB in size, we still have lot more systems to be added to this CALM system. 

We afraid 24GB is not enough for larger landscape like ours which have systems in RISE with SAP and on-prem.

Can we extend the CloudALM memory beyond 24GB size? SAP Note DIGITS - How to request SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension implies a restriction upto 24GB, if its upper limit, will there be increase of tenant size beyond 24GB in the future? 

If yes when do we expect that increase?

Thanks


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Cloud ALM Tenant extension greater than 24GB
entry.content:
Greetings from SAP Support.

Of course you can extend the CloudALM memory beyond 24GB size.

The 24 GB mentioned in KBA3590742 - How to request SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension is only an example. It illustrates a case where a customer procures two SAP Cloud ALM tenant extension products, resulting in:

  • 8 GB granted by the standard SAP Cloud ALM tenant

  • 8 GB √ó 2 granted by the two extensions

Totaling 8 + 8 √ó 2 = 24 GB.

In your scenario, you can purchase additional SAP Cloud ALM tenant extension products based on your requirements, and your available memory will increase accordingly.

In general, you will gain 8 + 8 √ó N GB, where N is the number of tenant extensions you have purchased.

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: BW Data Product Generator to Databricks Enterprise Capability
entry.content:
In this blog, I will cover getting BW Business Content data into Databricks using the following 4 steps:

  1. Enable the BW Data Product Generator in the SAP BW (7.5 or BW/4HANA) instance.
  2. Run the BW Data Product Generator on the BW Content
  3. Create the Data Product based on the BW Data‚ÄÉ           
  4. Delta Share the Data Product to Enterprise Databricks. 

Step 1 - Enable the BW Data Product Generator in the SAP BW (7.5 or BW/4HANA) instance.

Installation documentation is via the note at: https://me.sap.com/notes/3590400/E 

To install the BW Data Product Generator the current condition applies (speak to your SAP team for potential options to this): 

You have an SAP Business Warehouse, private cloud edition system (in SAP Business Data Cloud) in place and the object store in SAP Datasphere is enabled. Now, you want to connect to your SAP BW system to your existing SAP Business Data Cloud tenant and the connection is not configured.

In addition to the installation guide, making sure the Note Analyzer for Data Product Generator is run successfully. 

The good news in running the SAP_BW_BDC_CONFIGURATION task, is it is now re-runnable and you can reuse the same target space (BWDPG) in my case.  I won't go through the details of running the installation - but it relatively straight forward using the documentation - making sure you have the certificates corrected assigned in the BWPCE STRUST. 

Once successfully installing the BW DPG, you can access the Data Subscriptions Tile (in BW/4HANA) :

Associated Details :

 Also available via the SAP GUI, for use in BW 7.5 :

Step 2 - Run the BW Data Product Generator on the BW Content

In the next steps, I will use the BW Cockpit version (It is similiar using the GUI)

Initially creating and selecting a source:

The following BW InfoProviders can be used in a subscription for the BW DPG:

  • Base Providers: InfoCubes, Datastore Objects (Classic and Advanced), InfoObjects (Masterdata)
  • Composite Provider, MultiProvider
  • Queries: Query-as-InfoProvider

 

And selecting the BW Content that is activated. 

Once saved, it still needs to be activated as per message below:

Also, as part of the Data Subscription, 

  • Settings : Allows Full or Delta execution mode, apply filters to the data extraction and add Process Chain Variants to the subscription.
  • Projections : Able to simpify the output columns

Once you have configured any settings, you can activate the Data Subscription:

 

Activating the Subscription will also create the Datasphere Local Table in the BWDPG space (accessible from the link in the BW DPG or via Datasphere: :

 

Now the Target table exists on the Object store, which can also be seen in the BWDPG.

Side Note: I originally deployed the BW DPG using an earlier release, and the target objects where the Semantics Usage Type was : Local Table (Relational Dataset). Now after applying some recent notes it is now  : Local Table (Fact)

As the Data Subscription is now ready, it can be run directly from the Subscription screen:

Viewing the executions:

Now the data from BW exists in Datasphere Object store and if selected, can be delta updated as required 

I have shown the BW/4HANA Cockpit for the above, but it's also fully available for the GUI as well:

Viewing the BW Data from Datasphere:

Step 3 - Create the Data Product based on the BW Data

I won't cover every step in this process, as there are other blogs that do this, but essentially

The new Data Product, will use the BWDPG space:

Then add the 2 Data Products - Purchase Order Header and Line Items BW generated objects:

Then change the status of the Data Product to Listed. Once the Data Product is Listed, then it can be Delta Shared in the BDC Cockpit.

Step 4 - Delta Share the Data Product to Enterprise Databricks. 

Within the Business Data Cloud Cockpit, the new BW Data Product is available:

Sharing the Data Product to Enterprise Databricks is via the share button. I have already added the BDC Partner Connector for the DataBricks instance (seperate to this doco)

The sharing to Enterprise Databricks is quick and easy (no effort around ETL):

Within the Databricks environment, accessing the Catalog Explorer and the BDC Connect provider:

The difference with Delta Sharing from BDC to Enterprise Databricks (as compared to SAP Databricks) is the requirement to select the mount point for the Delta share:

Once mounted, the SAP Data Product can be accessed directly in the Catalog:

From here, users can perform all the advanced features of Databricks on the SAP BW data. 

This has been a basic end to end showcase - hopefully will have time to add in tips and tricks as we build out more customer Use Cases. 

Please post any questions and I can try to answer them.

entry.title: Building Trust in AI: SAP Business AI earns ISO/IEC 42001 Certification
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping how businesses operate, innovate, and serve their customers. But as AI becomes more deeply embedded into enterprise systems, ensuring that it behaves responsibly is just as important as making it powerful. 

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre proud to share that‚ÄØSAP Business AI has achieved ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification‚ÄØ‚Äî the‚ÄØworld‚Äôs first international standard for Artificial Intelligence Management Systems (AIMS). 
This certification covers‚ÄØJoule,‚ÄØSAP AI Core, and‚ÄØSAP AI Launchpad, reinforcing SAP‚Äôs long-standing commitment to building trustworthy, transparent, and ethical AI‚ÄØacross our products and services. 

Why This Matters 

Responsible AI isn‚Äôt just a principle. It‚Äôs a prerequisite for scaling AI safely in enterprise environments. The ISO/IEC 42001 standard provides a structured framework that guides how organizations manage AI across strategy, governance, data, compliance, and sustainability. 

For SAP, this certification validates that our approach to AI meets globally recognized standards for‚ÄØfairness, accountability, reliability, and security. It means our customers and partners can rely on SAP AI solutions that are developed, deployed, and maintained with integrity. 

What the Certification Covers 

The certification recognizes SAP‚Äôs efforts to embed responsible AI practices throughout the entire AI lifecycle: 

  • Establishing a comprehensive‚ÄØAI Management System (AIMS)‚ÄØaligned with ISO 42001. 
  • Integrating‚ÄØAI security, ethics, and compliance controls‚ÄØat every stage of AI development. 
  • Enabling‚ÄØcross-functional collaboration‚ÄØamong engineering, legal, governance, and compliance teams. 
  • Successfully passing an‚ÄØindependent third-party audit‚ÄØthat assessed SAP‚Äôs operational excellence in AI governance. 

The certification scope includes‚ÄØJoule,‚ÄØSAP AI Core, and‚ÄØSAP AI Launchpad, along with SAP‚Äôs internal IT processes and AI governance policies. 

Responsible AI in Practice 

The ISO 42001 certification underscores that SAP Business AI is built on the foundation of responsible AI. 
In practice, this means: 

  • Fairness and Transparency:‚ÄØAI results are explainable, unbiased, and clearly communicated to end users. 
  • Reliability and Security:‚ÄØAI models are developed and deployed with robust safeguards around data use, access, and protection. 
  • Ethical Alignment:‚ÄØEvery AI solution undergoes an ethics evaluation to ensure consistency with SAP‚Äôs sustainability and compliance goals. 
  • Continuous Adaptability:‚ÄØGovernance and risk management evolve as new technologies and regulations emerge. 

Benefits for Our Ecosystem 

For‚ÄØcustomers and partners, this milestone brings clear advantages: 

  • Confidence that SAP AI systems are developed and managed under a certified, globally recognized framework. 
  • Reduced compliance burden through alignment with international and regional AI regulations. 
  • Stronger data integrity and security safeguards that protect sensitive business information. 
  • The ability to demonstrate responsible AI usage within their own operations and industries. 

Even for SAP teams, the ISO 42001 certification is more than a badge of compliance. It has been a powerful catalyst for collaboration. It‚Äôs brought together experts in technology, policy, and compliance to strengthen how we design, test, and deliver AI. This shared framework helps us innovate faster and smarter, with accountability built into every step. 

A Step Toward the Future 

The ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification is a key milestone in SAP‚Äôs ongoing commitment to‚ÄØresponsible AI and customer success. It strengthens the foundation we‚Äôve built to ensure every advancement in‚ÄØSAP Business AI delivers innovation with integrity. 

As AI evolves, so will SAP‚Äôs dedication to keeping it‚ÄØreliable, transparent, and aligned with our customers‚Äô trust and business goals. 

Learn more about SAP Business AI‚ÄØand how we‚Äôre shaping the future of responsible enterprise AI.

entry.title: Required Scope Items for ISO 20022 Payment File Output in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
We are considering implementing a process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to output payment files in ISO 20022 format (Pain.001, etc.) for foreign remittances and manually upload them to the bank's web banking system.
We‚Äôre located in japan.

After reviewing the Help Portal and Best Practices documentation, I found conflicting information regarding the mandatory requirements:
Information Found:

"Advanced Payment Management" Help: States that SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity activation is required
"Advanced Payment Management (4MT)" Best Practices: States that SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (16R) is not mandatory but strongly recommended
"Bank Integration via File Interface (1EG)": Supports ISO 20022, can be used without Multi-Bank Connectivity with additional configuration
"Basic Payment Management": Uses a data model similar to ISO 20022

Questions:
To output payment files in ISO 20022 format (Pain.001, etc.), are the following scope items mandatory?

Advanced Payment Management (4MT) - Required?
Advanced Bank Account Management (J77) - Required?
Advanced Cash Processing (J78) - Required?
SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (16R) - Required?

Or is it possible to output ISO 20022 format files with only "Bank Integration via File Interface (1EG)"?
If anyone has experience with this, I would greatly appreciate your insights.

entry.title: Mejorando tu Comprensi√≥n del Libro de Inventarios y Balances de Per√∫: Nueva Documentaci√≥n
entry.content:
Soy Mait√™, desarrolladora de asistencia al usuario en SAP Globalization, y trabajo en el √°rea financiera. Como parte de mi rol, me complace compartir las √∫ltimas actualizaciones en la documentaci√≥n del reporte Libro de Inventarios y Balances de Per√∫ en SAP Document and Reporting Compliance. Explora los aspectos destacados a continuaci√≥n para descubrir c√≥mo estas mejoras pueden ayudarte con el reporte!

El reporte

El Libro de Inventarios y Balances de Per√∫ est√° actualmente disponible en SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition y SAP S/4HANA. El reporte organiza los saldos de las cuentas de mayor en catorce libros, siguiendo los requerimientos del PCGE (Plan Contable General Empresarial) y de la SUNAT (Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y de Administraci√≥n Tributaria).

Mejoras recientes en la documentaci√≥n

Para ayudarte a comprender mejor el reporte, hemos a√±adido una p√°gina nueva a la documentaci√≥n. Esta nueva p√°gina proporciona detalles sobre campos espec√≠ficos, agrupados seg√∫n configuraciones y caracter√≠sticas. Nuestro objetivo es aclarar las relaciones entre ciertos campos del reporte y las configuraciones necesarias antes de ejecutarlo.
Nueva p√°gina agregada en SAP Help Portal

 

Tablas estructuradas para mayor claridad

Hemos organizado la documentaci√≥n en cinco tablas:

  • Tabla 1: Campos relacionados con las jerarqu√≠as FSV y G/L Account

Esta tabla destaca los campos asociados con la configuraci√≥n de jerarqu√≠as de la aplicaci√≥n Manage Global Hierarchies y se enfoca en dos tipos de jerarqu√≠a: Financial Statement Versions (FSV) y G/L Account.

  • Tabla 2: Campos relacionados con el plan de cuentas alternativo

Detalla los campos relacionados con la configuraci√≥n del plan de cuentas alternativo usado para requerimientos legales espec√≠ficos en Per√∫.

  • Tabla 3: Campos Tax Number Type y Tax Number relacionados con el plan de cuentas alternativo

Ofrece detalles sobre campos relacionados con impuestos asociados a la configuraci√≥n del plan de cuentas alternativo.

  • Tabla 4: Otros campos en el reporte

Proporciona informaci√≥n sobre otros campos, explicando sus fuentes de datos y c√≥mo los completa el sistema.

  • Tabla 5: Campos opcionales en el reporte

Por √∫ltimo, esta tabla presenta los campos opcionales incluidos en nuestra soluci√≥n y explica c√≥mo los completa el sistema, aunque no son requeridos por la SUNAT.

Conclusi√≥n

Esperamos que estas actualizaciones en la documentaci√≥n faciliten tu trabajo con el reporte Libro de Inventarios y Balances. Puedes encontrarlas en la documentaci√≥n del reporte enlazada abajo:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Inventory and Balance Ledger
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition y SAP S/4HANA: Inventory and Balance Ledger

Te invitamos a explorar estas tablas en el SAP Help Portal y a compartir cualquier pregunta o comentarios que tengas. ¬°Ser√°n bienvenidos!

Por √∫ltimo, pero no menos importante, sigue SAP Document and Reporting Compliance en la comunidad para recibir actualizaciones.

Gracias y hasta la pr√≥xima,

Mait√™ Bohn

entry.title: My Expert Playlist - SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Hello, dear influencers, experts, and friends from the SAP Community!

It‚Äôs finally that time of the year again: SAP TechEd Season!
This year feels extra special to me‚Äîit‚Äôs the first SAP TechEd happening in Germany since I moved here, and I couldn‚Äôt be more excited.

When it comes to building my personal TechEd agenda, it has never been both so easy and so difficult at the same time.

Why difficult?
Because my curiosity is endless. Over my (long) SAP career, I‚Äôve worked across many areas: from writing ABAP code to designing modern user interfaces, from integration to solution and enterprise architecture‚Äîwhere technology truly meets business. I love exploring how technology and business merge, so naturally, I‚Äôd like to attend almost every session across the board.

Why easy?
Because priorities are clear this year: AI.
My laser focus will be on everything around custom AI scenarios‚Äîhow we as engineers can build AI extensions, create and extend Joule AI agents, and leverage the SAP AI Foundation. I believe many of the new challenges (and opportunities!) will emerge here, and I can‚Äôt wait to discover how SAP‚Äôs newest innovations will empower us.

That said, I‚Äôve shortlisted around 30 sessions I‚Äôd love to attend. Realistically, some I‚Äôll have to catch later via SAP TechEd Virtual‚Äîbut here are my Top 3 ‚Äúmust-watch‚Äù sessions:

 

My Top 3 SAP TechEd 2025 Sessions

  • CT1245 | Hugging Face Transformers in AI Foundation
    I‚Äôm learning to use Hugging Face models, so I‚Äôm curious to see how they work within the SAP AI Foundation. This feels like a new superpower for building advanced AI scenarios.

  • AI160 | Build your own AI agent‚Äìbased solution with the generative AI hub
    Agents are another game-changing technology. Spending two hours diving deep into building custom AI agents to extend SAP products sounds like time very well invested.

  • PAR102 | From MCP to Joule: Unlocking SAP data and AI innovation with Microsoft
    I‚Äôve been exploring how SAP AI Foundation can be integrated with cloud providers beyond the Generative AI Hub. This session will be a great opportunity to hear directly from Microsoft experts on their approach.

  • Bonus: AI101 | Optimize prompts and explore models with the generative AI hub
    Prompt engineering is one of the core skills for creating effective custom AI solutions. This session promises plenty of practical insights to sharpen that skill.

Of course, I wish I could attend everything‚Äîbut thankfully, many sessions will be available later via SAP TechEd Virtual.

In addition to the AI-focused ones, I‚Äôll also keep a close eye on all sessions related to Joule in the context of ABAP and CAP development‚Äîbecause at the end of the day, AI custom scenarios often start right there (with a little help from Python).

Final Thoughts

To all my fellow SAP Community colleagues:
I wish you an inspiring and knowledge-packed SAP TechEd season. May your curiosity be fueled and your learning appetite at least partly satisfied.

Let‚Äôs keep in touch and exchange our learnings in the weeks to come.

All the best,
Douglas

entry.title: Re: BADI which will be triggered during batch creation
entry.content:
Ah, I see exactly what you‚Äôre trying to do: you want to update batch characteristics automatically whenever a batch is created, regardless of whether the batch is created via CO1, VA01, MIGO, COR6N, CO15, MSC1N*, etc. You‚Äôre looking for a single enhancement point (BADI or user-exit) that triggers for batch creation. 

  • Single enhancement option: BADI_MATERIAL_BADI ‚Üí CHANGE_BATCH

  • Works for: MIGO, MSC1N, COR6N, CO15, sometimes CO1.

  • For VA01, it may require additional logic in batch assignment or delivery save.

  • Use SY-TCODE to differentiate source transaction.

entry.title: New Clean Core Extensibility KPIs arrive on the RISE with SAP Dashboard
entry.content:
Clean Core Extensibility Model goes RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard

We are thrilled to introduce another significant update to the RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard, delivering more transparent and structured insights into the clean core status of your custom extensions.

The latest release of the RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard in SAP Cloud ALM integrates SAP's new Clean Core Level Concept, an enhanced maturity model that categorizes extensions into four levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity and upgrade safety.

Updated Clean Core Extensibility Model

 

To power these new insights, the dashboard now supports the manual import of check results from the ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC).

Note:

As a prerequisite, you need to add the required ATC checks for clean core to your existing global standard ATC check variant. Relevant ATC checks for clean core are:

  • Allowed SAP enhancement technologies
  • Usage of APIs
  • Critical Statements

Your ATC variant can also include additional ATC checks. However, please be aware that these are not taken into account for the display in the RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard but will result in a larger ATC Check export file which again may cause the file import to fail (maximum file size is restricted to 100 MB).

 

Highlights of this Release

** Technical Debt Score **

This new KPI provides an aggregated score representing the technical debt of all custom objects in your system. It is weighted based on the severity of references to SAP objects, with a higher score indicating greater technical debt. A three-month trend indicates an increase or decrease in the score and thus helps you monitor whether your system's maintainability is improving or not.

Technical Debt Score KPI in System View of RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard

 

** Clean Core Share **

The Clean Core Share offers a comprehensive overview of how your system‚Äôs custom objects are distributed across the A-D clean core levels. This visualization helps you:

  • visualize your system‚Äôs custom code distribution
  • quickly identify areas needing immediate attention and improvement (e.g. decreasing the share of Level D Objects)
  • track improvement over time
  • make strategic decisions to achieve a clean core

Distribution of customer objects across clean core levels

 

These enhancements underscore our commitment to providing an actionable and comprehensive dashboard.
We encourage you to leverage these new features to guide your strategic decisions and ensure a successful clean core journey.

For more information about extensibility-related KPIs in RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard, see https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/extensibility?locale=en-US on SAP Help Portal.

 Stay tuned for more‚Ä¶

entry.title: Re: CDS view I_EQUIPMENTDATA for BW extraction: Why shoul...
entry.content:
Hi Yvonne,

"... do not enhance e.g. cds view i_equipmentdata directly, it will work but this will cause trouble during the next update. "

------------------------

There's code correction note for this standard CDS, like: 3193300 - I_EquipmentData - numeric overflow dump So if custom coding is implemented in this CDS, the next update (with note implementation or system upgrade ) may impact the customization. 

However if you use 'extend view I_EquipmentData with Z_E_I_EQUIPMENTDATA' without changing the I_EquipmentData itself, it'll be OK.

Regards,

entry.title: How does the Microsoft Dynamics 365 suite help streamline business operations across departments?
entry.content:
Many growing businesses struggle to manage multiple departments ‚Äî from finance and sales to supply chain and customer service ‚Äî using disconnected systems. This often leads to inefficiencies, data silos, and communication gaps.

The Microsoft Dynamics 365 suite offers an integrated set of applications that connect departments through a single platform, improving collaboration and productivity.

I‚Äôd like to hear from the community:

  • How has your organization benefited from using the Microsoft Dynamics 365 suite to streamline operations?
  • Which modules or features have made the biggest impact on cross-department collaboration?
  • What challenges did you face during implementation, and how did you overcome them?

Let‚Äôs share insights and real-world experiences to help others understand how Dynamics 365 can truly optimize business processes across all departments.

Drop your thoughts, experiences, or tips below ‚Äî your input can help other businesses make smarter digital transformation decisions.

entry.title: What's new: SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning ‚Äì 2511
entry.content:
In this blog, we will explore the latest updates to SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP). I will focus on the key highlights and new features introduced with release 2511. 

Enhancements in the SAPIBP1 Sample Planning Area:

In the latest updates to the SAPIBP1 sample planning area, the following main enhancements have been introduced.

  • Supply lead time calculations in inventory optimization algorithms previously used equal statistical weight of historical data from all past periods. With the introduction of the two new key figures for production and transportation lead time for historical recency factor, you can now apply a factor, giving more weight to recent periods while reducing the influence of older ones.
  • To improve data clarity and the usability of the planning area, we have simplified the calculation and decimal settings of several key figures.

 New Content for Sample Planning Area I_SAPIBP2:

We are now offering 17 new solution processes for the new planning area, Integrated Business Planning (I_SAPIBP2). In general, we have migrated and improved the existing solution processes, which were based on the Unified Planning Area (SAPIBP1) and Order-Based Planning using Flexible Master Data (SAP7F). As a guiding principle, we are delivering the most important solution processes with release 2511 and plan to deliver the remaining solution processes in subsequent releases.

The following figure provides an overview of the solution processes included in the 2511 delivery. As shown, solution processes are available for all IBP applications. Additionally, we have renamed the Sales & Operations Planning (S&OP) process to Sales, Inventory, and Operations Planning (SIOP), as an inventory review step has now been included in this process.

Overview solution processes based on planning area I_SAPIBP2

Content-wise, this package includes Excel planning views, planner workspaces, analytic stories, and sample data, all adapted and ready to be used for the I_SAPIBP2 planning area. Of course, you will also find a detailed configuration guide describing the setup activities required to deploy SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning, as well as detailed test scripts outlining the step-by-step execution of the solution processes in the system. All information about the new solution processes is available on the SAP Signavio Process Navigator.

Here are two examples of an analytic story and a planner workspace based on the planning area I_SAPIBP2.

Planner Workspace based on planning area I_SAPIBP2

Analytic story based on planning area I_SAPIBP2

Adding Joule and generative AI capabilities

In several solution processes, we have added the use of Joule and generative AI features. For example, we describe how you can utilize Joule capabilities for job scheduling in the solution process IBP Advanced Demand ‚Äì Segmentation (7LB). Another example is the use of the Master Data Health Check job with Joule, which provides functionalities for ensuring master data consistency. This usage is described in solution processes for inbound integration, such as IBP Foundation ‚Äì Inbound Real-Time Integration with SAP S/4HANA (7LN), or IBP ‚Äì Time-Series-Based Inbound Integration with SAP S/4HANA (3OF).

We have also added additional steps to show how generative AI can assist you in your day-to-day work. In our content, we now describe how you can use generative AI to analyze forecast results in the solution processes IBP for Demand ‚Äì Demand Planning (11V) and IBP Advanced Demand ‚Äì Demand Planning (7L6). In addition, the AI-Assisted Inventory Analysis is now available in the solution processes IBP for Inventory (11Z) and IBP Advanced Inventory Optimization ‚Äì Inventory Planning (7LC).

The screenshot shows an example of how generative AI can be used to analyze forecast results.

Generative AI analyzing forecast results.

IBP for maintenance, repair, and operations (MRO)

The solution process for IBP for maintenance, repair, and operations (MRO) (75C) has been enhanced to support inventory balancing and the inventory review process. Inventory balancing is used to distribute spare parts among different locations to avoid excess inventory at one site while shortages occur at another. In the inventory review process, the system recommends reorder points and safety stocks to improve the planning process, and it compares the current inventory parameters in the ERP system with those recommended in IBP.

Planner Workspace MRO

Sample Excel Planning Views

Another enhancement is a change in the handling of ActiveX controls in the SAP IBP add-in for Microsoft Excel. Until now, ActiveX controls were used in our Excel templates, for example, to store information about the planning view or for the chart section. With this release, all sample Excel planning views are based on the new sample VBA template, which uses Form controls instead of ActiveX controls (see SAP Note 1790530). For further information about ActiveX controls and the SAP IBP add-in for Microsoft Excel, see What's New in SAP IBP 2511: Changed Handling of ActiveX Controls.

Here some more useful links:

  • Highlight video of the new solution processes for Planning Area I_SAPIBP2
  • SAP Signavio Process Navigator to download all assets of SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning
  • Never heard about SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning ‚Äì check out this short video for more information
  • In case you want to learn more about SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning for Supply Chain I recommend our blog series. The first blog is available here.
  • What's New blog about SAP Integrated Business Planning 2511 is available here

Thank you for reading our release highlights blog. Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements in future releases.
